DMC.anecdote: DMC, or Dollfus-Mieg et Compagnie, is a textile company founded in Mulhouse in 1746.
DMC is particularly known for its brand of embroidery thread, called "Mouliné Spécial".
The headquarters of DMC in Mulhouse is located in a historic building that was constructed in 1846.
A maximum of 30000 people have worked at DMC.
In 1800, the company changed its name to Dollfus-Mieg & Compagnie, or DMC, after the marriage of Jean-Henri Dollfus with Anne-Marie Mieg.

Cité ouvrière.anecdote: The Cité ouvrière of Mulhouse was built starting in 1859 to house workers working in the city's textile factories.
The design of the houses in the Cité ouvrière was done by 2mile Muller, whose name is now given to a hospital.
The dwellings in the Cité ouvrière are called "Carré Mulhousien".
Ahead of its time, a rental-purchase system for houses was implemented.
It was designed by young industrialists from the city, including Jean Dollfus from the Dollfus-Mieg company, textile manufacturers since 1746 and coal owners since 1812.
The Cité ouvrière of Mulhouse brought together more than 10% of the inhabitants of the municipality of Mulhouse at the end of the 19th century.
The Cité ouvrière of Mulhouse is considered one of the most remarkable model housing projects in Europe.
The Cité ouvrière is open to visitors and offers guided tours to discover its history and architecture.
The Cité ouvrière was built in several stages from 1853 to 1897 and has 1,243 single-family homes.

Ancienne gare de Mulhouse.anecdote: The former Mulhouse train station was built in 1841 and was the city's first train station.
It was designed by the French architect Louis-François Cassas.
During World War II, the former Mulhouse train station was severely damaged.
It was replaced by another train station in 1906.
